main.name: Scott Harvey
main.description: I have over 15 years of experience with web development technologies such as JavaScript, Adobe ColdFusion, MS SQL Server, Oracle, HTML, and CSS. I am looking to apply these skills in a Full Stack Developer position working with the MERN stack (MongoDB, Express.js, React.js, Node.js). I have been learning this stack over the last six months and will complete the Full Stack Developer boot camp at Hyperion Dev in September 2019.
main.bio:
I'm dry-humored and the most socialable introvert you will meet - for example - my partner and I have been to over 25 weddings together and I've dragged her to the majority of them. I enjoy traveling and still find it amazing that I have been fortunate enough to travel to about 30 countries on 6 continents - most recently Nepal and Indonesia.

I enjoy developing with ColdFusion because it is relatively easy and feature rich. It is a shame that Adobe hasn't done more for ColdFusion. Perhaps they should open source their version of CFML in order to get more developers involved and boost the profile of ColdFusion. Then again, ColdFusion is essentially a Java framework so perhaps touting that could help ColdFusion could raise its profile.

Currently, I am attending a bootcamp where I am learning the MERN stack. It will be nice to have another tool in my toolbox and the potential opportunities that come with it. I think an ideal opportunity would be one where I get to use my knowledge of ColdFusion and could work on porting the application to the MERN stack or (a similar stack).

Professionally, I value a sense of ownership most of all. The position that I recall most fondly was at CLR where I built an intranet for them from the ground up. I was responsible for all aspects of the project - managing web hosting including database and web server setup, database architecture / design, and software development. As I automated CLR's processes I felt great pride to be able to develop software that was fostering communication between employees and making work easier for them.

I enjoy a challenge and I believe that if you aren't in a little over your head you will not grow. I'm looking for the next challenge.

bootcampProjects.title: Currency Converter / Three Card Monte
bootcampProjects.overlayText: Used create-react-app to bootstrap a ReactJS app that allows the user to choose between a currency converter and a Three-card Monte game.
bootcampProjects.assignment:
Create an app that allows the user to choose between two functions – a currency converter and a Three-card Monte game.

The user should be able to enter a figure in dollars and the app should calculate and display the amount in South African Rands, UK pounds and Euros. The components that display the converted values should be children of the conversion component.

The user should be shown three ‘Card’ components that they can click. When the user clicks on a ‘card’ the card should be ‘turned’ to reveal a message which either indicates that they’ve won a prize or that they’ve lost. They should only be able to pick one ‘card’ with each try. Once they’ve picked a ‘card’ they should no longer be able to click the ‘cards’ but should either be able to ‘Try again’ or ‘Quit’. The winning card should be different each time.
bootcampProjects.solution:
Used create-react-app to bootstrap a ReactJS app that allows the user to choose between a currency converter and a Three-card Monte game.

The currency converter fetches the current exchange rates from https://apilayer.com/ in order to convert currency between US Dollars, Euros, Pounds Sterling, and South African Rands.

The Three-Card Monte game is a simple game of chance where the player picks one of three cards.

In addition to the assignment's requirements the game also gives feedback about the winning or losing streak that the player is having.

bootcampProjects.overlayText: Used create-react-app to bootstrap a ReactJS app that displays the current weather in the city of the user's choice by fetching it from the OpenWeatherMap API.
bootcampProjects.assignment: Create a ReactJS app that will display the weather in a city of the user’s choice. The user should be able to enter or select the name of the city that they would like to see the weather for. The app should get the weather by fetching the OpenWeatherMap API
bootcampProjects.solution:
Used create-react-app to bootstrap a ReactJS app that displays the current weather in the city of the user's choice by fetching it from the OpenWeatherMap API.

The app adds the user's previous choices to a selector that triggers a fresh API call to the OpenWeatherMap API.

In order to improve on the assigned project I also used the Google Maps API to fetch and auto-suggest names of cities as the user types.
